reviews.review_text: This has a pretty interesting plot and Salvo does not seem to be so obsessed with his age.  Normally I’m not a huge fan of the Mafia storylines but this was quite good and kept me guessing the entire time.  In fact, I’m still not quite sure of the ending.  I guess it ends well for Montalbano but to be honest, I’m not quite totally certain of that.  Anyway, is it possible this is the last of the Montalbano books?  I think I now have read them all.  It has taken me several years and if you have read my reviews you’ll find that some I liked, others I did not.  I am a huge fan of the movies and they are why I read the books.  As I’ve already written, the books are different and in fact Salvo (imho) is not all that likable in the books.  In fact he is kind of a jerk.  In the movies, he most definitely is not a jerk.  At any rate, the series was fun to read but maybe I am ready to move on.  But before I go, I just want to reiterate how attached I have become to all the characters in the books: Catarella, Fazio, Mimi... and all the rest.  Camilleri has concocted a family that will be impossible to forget.  And some day I would love to go to Sicily... although in my embarrassment I now can finally admit:  I don’t like (nor eat) seafood.  Bueno, Salvo.  Bueno.
Another great book by this very Sicilian writer.  Very nice.

summary:
An Inspector Montalbano Mystery

Two deaths lead Inspector Montalbano into investigations of corruption and power in the twentieth installment of the New York Times bestselling series

Montalbano investigates a robbery at a supermarket, a standard case that takes a spin when manager Guido Borsellino is later found hanging in his office. Was it a suicide? The inspector and the coroner have their doubts, and further investigation leads to the director of a powerful local company.

Meanwhile, a girl is found brutally murdered in Giovanni Strangio’s apartment—Giovanni has a flawless alibi, and it’s no coincidence that Michele Strangio, president of the province, is his father. Weaving together these two crimes, Montalbano realizes that he’s in a difficult spot where political power is enmeshed with the mafia underworld.

“The idiosyncratic Montalbano is totally endearing.” The New York Times
